case_name: Poona Electric Supply Co., Ltd. v. The Revenue

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 633 and 634 of 1964 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 633 and 634 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals from the judgement and order dated July 23 and 24, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 61 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgement and order dated July 23 and 24, 1962 of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 61 of 1961.

facts.text: The appellant is the Poona Electric Supply Co., Ltd., called the Company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, the Poona Electric Supply Co., Ltd., hereinafter called the Company,

facts.text: The Company carried on the business of distribution of electricity in the city of Poona under a licence issued by the Government.

anchor.surface_text: carried on the business of distribution of electricity in the city of Poona under a licence issued by the Government.

facts.text: Under the Electricity Supply Act, 1948 (Act 54 of 1948), the Company's clear profit in any year should not, as far as possible, exceed the amount of reasonable return as defined under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under the relevant provisions of the Electricity  Supply  Act, 1948,  Act 54 of 1948 , hereinafter called the Act, the Companys clear profit in any year should number, as far as possible, exceed the amount of reasonable return as defined under the Act.

facts.text: The excess, if any, after making some deductions, the Company has to distribute to its consumers in the form of rebate.

anchor.surface_text: The excess, if any, after making some deductions, the Company has to distribute to its companysumers in the form of rebate.

facts.text: During the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 the Company claimed deduction of Rs. 42,148/- and Rs. 77,138/- credited to Consumers Benefit Reserve Account.

anchor.surface_text: During the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 the Company claimed deduction of two amounts of Rs. 42,148/- and Rs. 77,138/- for the said two years from its taxable income as they were credited to Consumers Benefit Reserve Account.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim and on appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: and on appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner agreed with the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal accepted the contention of the appellant and allowed the deductions.

anchor.surface_text: On a further appeal, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal accepted the companytention of the appellant and allowed the deductions.

facts.text: At the instance of the Revenue, the Tribunal submitted question of law to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Revenue, the Tribunal submitted the following question of law to the High Court of Judicature at Bombay for its opinion

facts.text: Question: Whether Rs. 42,148/- in 1953-54 and Rs. 77,138/- in 1954-55 were deductible in computing income, profits and gains from the assessee's business.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the two sums of Rs. 42,1481- in the assessment year 1953-54 and Rs. 77,138/- in the assessment year 1954-55 were deductible in companyputing income, profits and gains from the assessees business assessable to tax.

facts.text: Division Bench of Bombay High Court answered the question in the negative and against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the said High Court answered the question in the negative and against the appellant.

facts.text: Present appeals filed by the Company after obtaining certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeals have been filed by the Company after obtaining the requisite certificate from the High Court.

facts.text: The Company follows the mercantile system of accounting.

anchor.surface_text: The Company follows the mercantile system of accounting and, therefore, the amount of rebate so reserved is deductible for arriving at the companymercial profit of the Company in the year when the statutory liability arises

facts.text: Statutory liability for the two amounts arose in the accounting years of 1952 and 1953.

facts.text: No person can supply electric energy in any area unless he has obtained a licence from the State Government under s. 3(1) of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910.

anchor.surface_text: No person can supply electric energy in any area unless he has obtained a licence from the State Government under s. 3 1  of the Indian Electricity Act, 1910  9 of 1910 .

facts.text: Under Para. II of Sixth Schedule, if clear profit exceeds reasonable return, one-third of such excess not exceeding 7.5% of reasonable return at disposal of undertaking, half to be distributed as rebate or carried forward.

anchor.surface_text: Under Para. II thereof if the clear profit of a licence in any year of account is in excess of the amount of reasonable return, one-third of such excess, number exceeding 7 1/2 of the amount of reasonable return, shall be at the disposal of the undertaking one half of the said excess shall either be distributed in the form of a proportional rebate on the amounts companylected from the sale of electricity and meter rentals or carried forward in the accounts of the licensee for distribution to the companysumers in future in such manner as the State Government may direct.

facts.text: During the accounting years the assessee credited the said amounts to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of the Act, during the accounting years the assessee credited the said amounts to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account.

facts.text: It is not disputed that the assessee adopts the mercantile system of accounting.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the assessee adopts the mercantile system of accounting.

facts.text: The liability to return the amounts was incurred by the assessee during the relevant accounting years.

facts.text: Supreme Court answers the question in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee.

issues.text: Whether the two sums of Rs. 42,148/- in the assessment year 1953-54 and Rs. 77,138/- in the assessment year 1954-55 were deductible in computing income, profits and gains from the assessee’s business assessable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the two sums of Rs. 42,1481- in the assessment year 1953-54 and Rs. 77,138/- in the assessment year 1954-55 were deductible in computing income, profits and gains from the assessees business assessable to tax.

issues.text: whether the amount so returned or returnable by the licensee to his consumers is deductible for ascertaining his taxable income from his business under s. 10(1) or s. 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the amount so returned or returnable by the licensee to his consumers is deductible for ascertaining his taxable income from his business under s. 10 1  or s. 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: whether the amounts so reserved for future payment were deductible in computing the income, profits or gains from the assessee’s business for the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55.
whether the said amounts would be allowable deductions under s. 10(2)(xv) of the Act.

arguments.claim: There is a distinction between commercial profit of a company and clear profit under the Act; real profit under s. 10(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act determined only after excluding amount statutorily transferred to Consumers Benefit Reserve Account as rebate to customers.

anchor.surface_text: 1 There is a distinction between commercial profit of a company and clear profit under the Act---one is arrived at on commercial principles and the other is regulated by the statute the real profit of a company under s. 10 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act can be determined only after excluding the amount statutorily transferred to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account, for that amount represents a rebate to the customers of the excess amount collected from them.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: behalf the business was companyducted. In Young M. Inspector of Taxes  v. Racecourse Betting Control Board 1  the question that arose was whether the

arguments.court_reasoning: Real profits computed on commercial principles, not statutory clear profit; rebate not part of real income.

arguments.claim: Reservation of part of excess is statutory condition for business, hence expenditure wholly and exclusively for business purpose, deductible under s. 10(2)(xv) Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: 2 As the reservation of a part of the said excess is a statutory condition subject to which the Company carries on its business, it is an expenditure wholly and exclusively incurred for the purpose of the Companys business and, therefore, it is an allowance deductible under s. 10 2 xv  of the Income-tax Act for computing the profit of the Appellants business.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to decide as deductible under s.10(1).

arguments.claim: Under mercantile system of accounting, rebate reserved deductible in year statutory liability arises (1952 and 1953), not when paid.

anchor.surface_text: 3 The Company follows the mercantile system of accounting and, therefore, the amount of rebate so reserved is deductible for arriving at the commercial profit of the Company in the year when the statutory liability arises and not when the amount is actually paid and in the present case the statutory liability for the said two amounts arose in the accounting years of 1952 and 1953.

arguments.court_reasoning: Assessee follows mercantile system; liability accrued in relevant years; cites Calcutta Co. precedent.

arguments.claim: Transference of excess to consumers benefit reserve is apportionment/distribution of profit after earned, not deductible under s.10(1) IT Act.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Additional Solicitor General contended that 1 under the relevant provisions of the Act the transference of a part of the said excess to the consumers benefit reserve account would only amount to apportionment or distribution of the profit after it has been earned and, therefore, it is not a deductible item for ascertaining the profit of the Company under s. 10 1  of the Income-tax Act

court_response_anchor.surface_text: behalf the business was companyducted. In Young M. Inspector of Taxes  v. Racecourse Betting Control Board 1  the question that arose was whether the

arguments.court_reasoning: Equates clear profit (statutory) with commercial profit; distinction exists; rebate is deduction for real profit ascertainment.

arguments.claim: Amounts not expenditure wholly/exclusively for business; not incurred in course/for earning profits but apportioned from already earned profits.

anchor.surface_text: 2 the said amounts could not be said to be an expenditure wholly and exclusively incurred for the purpose of the business, as the expenditure was not incurred either during the course of the business or for the purpose of earning the profits of the business, but was only apportioned or distributed from and out of the profits already earned.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits. In a given case whether the outgoings fall in one or the other of the he

arguments.court_reasoning: Clear distinction between deductions for ascertaining profits and distributions out of profits; this is former.

arguments.claim: Clear profit under Sixth Schedule arrived after all deductions including taxes; distribution of excess is out of profits.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Additional Solicitor General took us though the various paragraphs of the Sixth Schedule to the Act and argued that under them the licensees clear profit was arrived at after all the deductions were made, including the appropriations for all taxes on income and profits and, therefore, the distribution of a part of the excess was only a distribution out of the profits.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f the managed companypany were number sufficient to pay a dividend of 6 per cent. The companytention of the Revenue that such a surrender of the compa

arguments.court_reasoning: Fallacy equates clear profit (statutory for rate control) with commercial profits (for tax); rules for rationalizing rates, not tax.

arguments.claim: Income-tax on real/commercial profits under s.10(1), not statutory profits; rebate compulsorily returned not part of real profits.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 10 1  of the Income-tax Act, tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head profits and gains of business in respect of profits and gains of any business carried on by him. The said profits and gains are not profits regulated by any statute, but profits in a business computed on business principles.

arguments.claim: Distinction between deductions for ascertaining profits and distributions out of profits; rebate is deduction.

anchor.surface_text: There is a clear-cut distinction between deductions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits.

arguments.claim: Clear profit (statutory for rates) differs from commercial profit (for tax); amounts reserved for rebate not part of real profits.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of the Act, during the accounting years the assessee credited the said amounts to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account. They were part of the excess amount paid to it and reserved to be returned to the consumers. They did not form part of the asssessee's real profits.

arguments.claim: Under mercantile accounting, accrued statutory liability deductible in year it arises.
Pondicherry Railway precedent: payment out of profits not deductible (distinguished).

anchor.surface_text: In Pondicherry Railway Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 . under an agreement... A payment out of profits and conditional on profits being earned cannot accurately be described as a payment made to earn profits.

arguments.claim: Union Cold Storage precedent: rent abatement deductible despite conditional on profits (analogous).

anchor.surface_text: Lord Macmillan himself in a later decision in The Union Cold Storage Co. Ltd., v. Adamson... explained his observations... Here the question is whether or not a deduction for rent has to be made in ascertaining the profits, and the question is not one of the distribution of profits at all.

arguments.claim: British Sugar Manufacturers precedent: payment reference to profits but for ascertaining profits, deductible (analogous).

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Court of Appeal in British Sugar Manufacturers, Ltd. v. Harris... Once you realise that... the word profits may be used in one sense for one purpose and in another sense for another purpose...

arguments.claim: Mersey Docks precedent: surplus to sinking fund is profit (distinguished as distribution).

anchor.surface_text: In Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v. Lucas 3 the harbour board... surplus income formed the sinking fund and was utilised to pay off the debts... rightly held that the said amount was utilised by the board from and out of its profits

arguments.claim: Sixth Schedule provisions incorporated in licence; mandate adjustment of rates, rebate of excess (descriptive).

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 57 1 of the Act the provisions of the Sixth Schedule... Under Para. II thereof if the clear profit... shall either be distributed in the form of a proportional rebate...

holdings.text: Under s. 10(1) of the Income-tax Act, tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head 'Profits and gains of business' in respect of the real profits and gains of any business computed on commercial principles, not statutory profits regulated by any statute.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 10  1  of the Income-tax Act, tax shall be payable by an assessee under the head profits and gains of business in respect of profits and gains of any business carried on by him. The said profits and gains are number profits regulated by any statute, but profits in a business companyputed on business principles.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Income-tax levied on commercial profits; statutory clear profit under Electricity Act for rate regulation, not tax; rebate compulsorily returned not real income.

holdings.text: The real profit of a businessman under s. 10(1) cannot include amounts returned by way of rebate to consumers under statutory compulsion; it is deductible as if not received.

anchor.surface_text: They are real profits and number numberional profits. The real profit of a businessman under s. 10 1 of the Income-tax Act cannot obviously include the amounts returned by him by way of rebate to the companysumers under statutory companypulsion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy: collecting excess by mistake and returning it not profit; substance over form.

holdings.text: There is a clear-cut distinction between deductions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits; the rebate here is a deduction for ascertaining real profits.

anchor.surface_text: There is a clear-cut distinction between deductions made for ascertaining the profits and distributions made out of profits. In a given case whether the outgoings fall in one or the other of the heads is a question of fact...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents distinguish: payments to earn/ascertain profits (deductible) vs out of profits (not); here former.

holdings.text: The amounts credited to Consumers Benefit Reserve Account did not form part of the assessee's real profits and are deductible under s.10(1) to arrive at taxable income from business.

anchor.surface_text: For the purposes of the Act, during the accounting years the assessee credited the said amounts to the Consumers Benefit Reserve Account. They were part of the excess amount paid to it and reserved to be returned to the companysumers. They did number form part of the asssessee's real profits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear profit statutory for rates; commercial profit for tax excludes reserved rebate.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether the amounts are allowable under s.10(2)(xv) as deductible under s.10(1).

anchor.surface_text: In this view it is number necessary to express our opinion on the question whether the said amounts would be allowable deductions under s. 10 2  xv  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue moot as resolved under primary provision s.10(1).

holdings.text: Under mercantile system of accounting adopted by assessee, the amounts reserved for rebate are deductible in the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55 as liability accrued then.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the amounts so reserved for future payment were deductible in companyputing the income, profits or gains from the assessees business for the assessment years 1953-54 and 1954-55. It is number disputed that the assessee adopts the mercantile system of accounting.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability incurred in relevant years; follows Calcutta Co. Ltd. precedent on accrual basis.

holdings.text: The question referred is answered in the affirmative in favour of the assessee; High Court order set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we answer the question referred to the High Court in the affirmative and in favour of the assessee. The order of the High Court is set aside.

precedents.citation: Pondicherry Railway Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: Pondicherry Railway Co., Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 . under an agreement with the French Colonial Government the railway companypany had to pay to the said Government half of its net profits calculated as provided thereunder. One of the questions that arose in the appeal was whether the appellant-company was entitled to deduct the payments made under the agreement with the said Government as being expenditure incurred solely for the purpose of earning such profits within s. 10 9  of the Income-tax Act.

precedents.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: A payment out of profits and conditional on profits being earned cannot accurately be described as a payment made to earn profits
precedents.cited_holding: A payment out of profits and conditional on profits being earned cannot accurately be described as a payment made to earn profits. It assumes that profits have first come into existence. But profits on their coming into existence attract tax at that point, and the revenue is not concerned with the subsequent application of the profits.

anchor.surface_text: Gresham Life Assurance .Society v. Styles 2 , proceeded to observe The word profits I think is to be understood in its natural and proper sense in a sense which no commercial man would misunderstand.

precedents.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v Styles
precedents.cited_proposition: Profits to be understood in natural sense; destination of profits immaterial for tax

precedents.citation: The Indian Radio and Cable Communications Cornpony, Ltd., The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay Presidency AdenC 1

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Radio and Cable Communications Cornpony, Ltd., The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay Presidency AdenC . There, their Lordships were dealing with a case of a joint venture by two companypanies and Lord Maugham pointed out thus It may be admitted that, as Mr. Latter companytended, it is number universally true to say that a payment the making of which is companyditional on profits being earned cannot properly be described as an expenditure incurred for the purpose of earning such profits.

precedents.case_name: Indian Radio and Cable Communications Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Payment conditional on profits not always excluded from earning profits; exception for commission
precedents.cited_holding: It is not universally true to say that a payment conditional on profits being earned cannot properly be described as an expenditure incurred for the purpose of earning such profits. The typical exception is payment of commission on profits.

anchor.surface_text: Pondicherry Railway Co. 2 has been modified.

precedents.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle that payment conditional on profits cannot be to earn profits

precedents.citation: The Union Cold Storage Co. Ltd., v. Adamson H. M. Inspector of Taxes 3

anchor.surface_text: The Union Cold Storage Co. Ltd., v. Adamson H. M. Inspector of Taxes 3 explained his observations in the Pondicherry Railway Co.s case 2 . There, the appellant-company leased lands and premises abroad under a deed reserving a particular rent per annum.

precedents.case_name: Union Cold Storage Co Ltd v Adamson
precedents.cited_proposition: Rent abatement deducted before ascertaining profits, not distribution
precedents.cited_holding: The question is whether or not a deduction for rent has to be made in ascertaining the profits, and the question is not one of the distribution of profits at all.

anchor.surface_text: Pondicherry Railway Co.s case 2

precedents.case_name: Pondicherry Railway Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Payment out of profits not to earn profits

precedents.citation: British Sugar Manufacturers, Ltd. v. Harris Inspector of Taxes 1

anchor.surface_text: British Sugar Manufacturers, Ltd. v. Harris Inspector of Taxes 1 is rather instructive. There, a companypany carrying on a manufacturing business agreed with two other companypanies to pay them a stated percentage of its net profits in companysideration of their giving to the companypany the full benefit of their technical and financial knowledge and experience

precedents.case_name: British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd v Harris
precedents.cited_proposition: Profits may be ascertained differently for different purposes; payments before taxable profits
precedents.cited_holding: Once you realise that as a matter of construction the word profits may be used in one sense for one purpose and in another sense for another purpose... the payment is to be taken into account in order to ascertain the profits.

precedents.citation: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Calcutta 1 emphasized the concept of real income in the context of payment of income-tax.

precedents.case_name: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v Commissioner of Income Tax Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: Tax only on real income of the taxpayer
precedents.cited_holding: only the real income of the taxpayer

precedents.citation: H.M. Kashiparekh Ca. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay North 1

anchor.surface_text: H.M. Kashiparekh Ca. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay North 1 . There, under the managing agency agreement the managing agent was under a duty to forgo up to one-third of its companymission where the profits of the managed companypany were not sufficient to pay a dividend of 6 per cent.

precedents.case_name: HM Kashiparekh & Co Ltd v Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay North
precedents.cited_proposition: Principle of real income applies to surrender of commission on commercial expediency
precedents.cited_holding: The principle of real income is not to be subordinated... when a surrender or concession or rebate in respect of managing agency commission is made on grounds of commercial expediency.

precedents.citation: Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v. Lucas 3

anchor.surface_text: Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v. Lucas 3 the harbour board was empowered by Act of Parliament to levy dock dues to be applied in maintaining the concern and in paying interest on moneys borrowed any surplus income remaining after meeting these charges was directed to be applied in forming a sinking fund to extinguish the debt incurred in the construction of the docks.

precedents.case_name: Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v Lucas
precedents.cited_proposition: Surplus carried to sinking fund is profit assessable to tax

precedents.citation: Paddington Burial Board v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 3

anchor.surface_text: Paddington Burial Board v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue 3 was also based on the same principle. Under a public Act of Parliament a burial ground was provided out of the poor rates, and fees were charged to persons using it any surplus of income over expenditure was applied in aid of the poor rates as required by the Act.

precedents.case_name: Paddington Burial Board v Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: Surplus applied to aid rates is profit assessable

precedents.citation: Young M. Inspector of Taxes v. Racecourse Betting Control Board 1

anchor.surface_text: Young M. Inspector of Taxes v. Racecourse Betting Control Board 1 the question that arose was whether the Racecourse Betting Control Board was entitled in computing the profits of the trade of totalisator operator for the years 1953-54 and 1954-55 to deduct certain payments.

precedents.case_name: Young v Racecourse Betting Control Board
precedents.cited_proposition: Voluntary payments not deductible as for purpose of trade

precedents.citation: Calcutta Co. Ltd., v. Commissioner Income-tax, West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Calcutta Co. Ltd., v. Commissioner Income-tax, West Bengal 1 that where an assessee maintained his accounts on mercantile basis, the accrued liability and the estimated expenditure which it would incur in discharging the same could be deducted from the income of the accounting year in which the said liability accrued.
